results.headline: Playground Rules: No Hitting, No Sex

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Children

results.summary_short: Todd Field’s superb film adaptation of the novel by Tom Perrotta  is challenging, accessible and hard to stop thinking about.

results.headline: Three Tales Revolving Around a Real Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Be With Me

results.summary_short: Although four stories are folded together in Eric Khoo’s elliptical film, it's the true story of a deaf and blind Singaporean woman that gives the movie its backbone.

results.headline: In an Epic of Nonverbal Desire, It Is the Details That Matter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken Sky

results.summary_short: Boy meets boy like you’ve never seen in Julián Hernández’s sex-drenched, extravagantly minimalist epic.

results.headline: An Oddball Army in a Cartoon Wilderness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Open Season

results.summary_short: Periodic bursts of cleverness and eye-popping imagery can’t disguise that this is just another movie full of jive-talking computer-generated animals with little new to say.

results.headline: Sad Sacks Seek Instruction in the Ways of Courtship

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of School for Scoundrels

results.summary_short: Billy Bob Thornton's estimable talents are squandered in this shoddy comedy directed by Todd Phillips ("Old School").

results.headline: Celebrating the Triumphant Return of the Pixies
results.display_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film about the Pixies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of LoudQUIETloud: A Film about the Pixies

results.summary_short: Boring people who made extraordinary music, the Pixies are inexplicable. In attempting to demystify them, this backstage pass to their 2004 reunion tour achieves the opposite.

results.headline: On Stage and Off With Three Veterans of the Comedy Scene

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Latin Legends of Comedy

results.summary_short: If it wasn’t true before, it’s certainly true with the appearance of “The Latin Legends of Comedy”: the word legend has been devalued to the point of worthlessness.

results.headline: Costner Is Back in the Water, and He’s Stoically Swimming to Save Everybody

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Guardian

results.summary_short: "The Guardian" is an action movie, a basic training movie, a swaggering sea adventure, a home front melodrama and an inspiring tough-love heroic teacher fable.

results.headline: An Innocent Abroad, Seduced by a Madman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last King of Scotland

results.summary_short: Kevin Macdonald's queasily enjoyable fiction film creates a portrait of the Ugandan dictator Idi Amin from inside the palace walls.

results.headline: A Parisian Love Story in Forward, and Sideways, Motion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Science of Sleep

results.summary_short: Michel Gondry's beguiling new film is so profoundly idiosyncratic, and so confident in its oddity, that any attempt to describe it is bound to be misleading.

results.headline: The Joy of Self-Inflicted Trauma

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jackass: Number Two

results.summary_short: Debased, infantile and reckless in the extreme, this compendium of body bravado and malfunction makes for some of the most fearless, liberated and cathartic comedy in modern movies.

results.headline: Children’s Boot Camp for the Culture Wars

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jesus Camp

results.summary_short: This riveting documentary explores Kids on Fire, a summer camp in Devils Lake, N.D., that grooms children to be soldiers in "God's army."

results.headline: Anger and Irregularities at the Voting Booth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Blackout

results.summary_short: In this furious documentary about the disenfranchisement of black voters, the director Ian Inaba builds a compelling case around the general elections of 2000 and 2004.

results.headline: The Minutia of Anime vs. the Lure of Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Train Man: Densha Otoko

results.summary_short: A simple tale of beauty, the geek and the Internet, this Japanese romantic comedy follows the halting courtship of a 22-year-old nerd and his subway crush.

results.headline: Even in a Place Like Paris, It’s Not Good to Live Forever

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Renaissance

results.summary_short: The grim, dystopian world of this animated French film is the product of a computer technique that evokes the sharp, linear style of a graphic novel.

results.headline: Southern Fried Demagogue and His Lurid Downfall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All The King's Men

results.summary_short: Like an electioneering candidate, Steve Zaillian's version of “All the King’s Men” makes a lot of promises but fails to deliver the goods.

results.headline: An Inside Look at a Band on the Rise
results.display_title: Los Lonely Boys: Cottonfields and Crossroads

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Los Lonely Boys: Cottonfields and Crossroads

results.summary_short: Hector Galán’s film about the Texas trio of brothers who won a Grammy in 2005 is a worshipful disappointment.

results.headline: A Boxer's Rise and Fall, With the Usual Stops in Between

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of They're Just My Friends

results.summary_short: The ambitiously genre-crossing yet disastrously executed “They’re Just My Friends” is hands down the most excruciatingly inept film to creep its way into theaters in some time.

results.headline: Volunteers in Unfriendly Skies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flyboys

results.summary_short: Empty headed and egregiously polite, this nostalgia trip to the First World War is what you’d get if Norman Rockwell directed “Top Gun.”

results.headline: Exile, Rehabilitation and Redemption for a Chinese Freedom Fighter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jet Li's Fearless

results.summary_short: Jet Li says goodbye (supposedly) to the martial arts genre with this decent blend of old-school chopsocky and new school superproduction.
